verses.text: A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.
verses.comment: The theme of controlling one's words is seen here and elsewhere in Proverbs and the New Testament, highlighting the power of speech.

verses.text: The tongue of the wise makes knowledge attractive, but the mouth of fools pours out foolishness.
verses.comment: The shaping of knowledge for edification is an aspect of wisdom—an early hint toward the idea of teaching with authority.

verses.text: The eyes of the LORD are in every place, watching the evil and the good.
verses.comment: God's omnipresence and all-seeing nature provide a foundation for moral accountability.

verses.text: Gentle speech is a tree of life, but twisted words break the spirit.
verses.comment: 'Tree of life' recalls Genesis, alluding to the power of words to give or diminish life.

verses.text: A fool despises his father's instruction, but the one who heeds correction is wise.
verses.comment: Heeding correction points to humility, a virtue central to spiritual growth and the broader tradition.

verses.text: In the house of the righteous there is much treasure, but the income of the wicked brings trouble.
verses.comment: True treasure is contrasted with ill-gotten gain—interpreted spiritually as reward for right living.

verses.text: The lips of the wise spread knowledge, not so the hearts of fools.
verses.comment: Instruction and the spreading of true knowledge is a recurring motif in wisdom literature.

verses.text: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright is His delight.
verses.comment: Right intention matters more than ritual; authentic worship is pleasing to God, foreshadowing the priority of the heart in worship in the new covenant.

verses.text: The way of the wicked is detestable to the LORD, but He loves him who pursues righteousness.
verses.comment: Pursuing righteousness is emphasized throughout wisdom literature and the teachings of Christ.

verses.text: Correction is harsh for him who forsakes the way; whoever hates reproof will die.
verses.comment: Accepting discipline is closely tied to spiritual life and perseverance.

verses.text: Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD—how much more the hearts of men!
verses.comment: This affirms God's full knowledge, a foundation for doctrines about judgment and conscience.

verses.text: A mocker does not love one who corrects him; he will not go to the wise.
verses.comment: The separation from wise counsel is itself a form of judgment.

verses.text: A joyful heart makes a cheerful face, but by sorrow of heart the spirit is crushed.
verses.comment: This links inner disposition to outward expression—joy as a fruit of the Spirit in the believer.

verses.text: The heart of him who has understanding seeks knowledge, but the mouths of fools feed on folly.
verses.comment: A hunger for true knowledge is set in opposition to the trivial pursuits of folly.

verses.text: All the days of the afflicted are evil, but the cheerful heart has a continual feast.
verses.comment: Inner joy is not dependent on circumstances, hinting at the interior peace promised in Christ.

verses.text: Better is a little with the fear of the LORD than great treasure and trouble with it.
verses.comment: Spiritual richness is preferable to material abundance, emphasizing contentment and reverence.

verses.text: Better is a dish of vegetables where love is, than a fattened ox with hatred.
verses.comment: Sacrificial love elevates the simplest meal; echoes the value Christ places on love over outward displays.

verses.text: A hot-tempered man stirs up conflict, but the slow to anger calms strife.
verses.comment: Self-control as a virtue paves the way for peace, strongly emphasized in pastoral epistles.

verses.text: The way of the lazy man is like a hedge of thorns, but the path of the upright is a level highway.
verses.comment: Industry vs. sloth is also a spiritual lesson about perseverance and the path of virtue.

verses.text: A wise son makes his father glad, but a foolish man despises his mother.
verses.comment: Familial relationships serve as a model for obedience—echoes of honoring one’s parents, which carries New Testament significance.

verses.text: Folly is a joy to him who is without sense, but a man of understanding walks straight ahead.
verses.comment: Contrasts temporary pleasures of sin with consistent pursuit of virtue and truth.

verses.text: Without counsel, plans fail; but with many advisers, they succeed.
verses.comment: Multitude of counsel hints at the importance of authoritative guidance in the community of faith.

verses.text: A man finds joy in a fitting reply—how good is a word spoken at the right time!
verses.comment: The right word encourages and builds up; speech in season has the power to bless.

verses.text: The path of life leads upward for the prudent, so that he may avoid Sheol below.
verses.comment: Wisdom provides deliverance from destruction, pointing ahead to the doctrine of eternal life.

verses.text: The LORD tears down the house of the proud, but He protects the widow’s border.
verses.comment: Divine justice defends the powerless, increasingly emphasized from the prophets to the teachings of Jesus.

verses.text: The thoughts of the wicked are detestable to the LORD, but gracious words are pure.
verses.comment: Purity of speech is linked to inner purity, foreshadowing Jesus' teaching about clean hearts.

verses.text: Whoever gains profit unjustly troubles his own house, but he who hates bribes will live.
verses.comment: Honest living preserves the household; echoes justice and integrity as core virtues.

verses.text: The heart of the righteous thinks before answering, but the mouth of the wicked gushes evil.
verses.comment: Prudence in speech aligns with the virtue of discernment.

verses.text: The LORD is far from the wicked, but He hears the prayer of the righteous.
verses.comment: The efficacy of intercession for the righteous is a theme developed in later scriptures.

verses.text: Bright eyes bring joy to the heart, and good news gives health to the bones.
verses.comment: Spiritual encouragement and the healing effect of gospel truth are seen here in seed form.

verses.text: Whoever listens to life-giving correction will dwell among the wise.
verses.comment: Receiving correction opens the way to true wisdom, closely tied to growth in holiness.

verses.text: He who ignores instruction despises himself, but whoever listens to correction gains understanding.
verses.comment: Listening and growth through discipline is emphasized as vital for spiritual maturity.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD teaches wisdom, and humility comes before honor.
verses.comment: The connection of humility to honor is later fulfilled perfectly in Christ, who humbled Himself and was exalted. Humble learning leads to true exaltation, both temporally and eternally.
